choices.text: Restrictive lung disease
Obstructive lung disease
Normal lung function
Interstitial lung disease

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with chronic cough and shortness of breath. Spirometry shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.60. What does this finding suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obstructive lung disease

 

Explanation:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (typically < 0.70) is a hallmark of obstructive lung diseases, where airflow is limited, such as COPD and asthma.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Restrictive lung disease: Characterized by reduced lung volumes with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal PFTs would show a normal FEV1/FVC ratio.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: A type of restrictive lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (< 0.70) on spirometry is indicative of obstructive lung disease, commonly seen in conditions like COPD and asthma.

choices.text: Normal residual volume (RV)
Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC)
Normal vital capacity (VC)
Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of smoking and progressive dyspnea presents with a barrel chest and expiratory wheezing. Which PFT finding is LEAST likely in this patient with suspected emphysema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal residual volume (RV)

 

Explanation:

 

Emphysema, a type of COPD, is characterized by air trapping and hyperinflation, leading to increased residual volume.

 

Other options

 

Option B. Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC): Common in emphysema due to air trapping.

 

Option C. Normal vital capacity (VC): While possible in early disease, VC often decreases as emphysema progresses.

 

Option D. Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio: Hallmark of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emphysema, expect increased residual volume (RV) due to air trapping, along with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and forced vital capacity (FVC).

choices.text: Tidal volume (TV)
Vital capacity (VC)
Functional residual capacity (FRC)
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)

questions.text: A medical student is using the following device to assess lung function in a patient with suspected asthma. Which of the following lung volumes cannot be directly measured using this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional residual capacity (FRC)

 

Explanation:

 

The given instrument is a hand held spirometer. Spirometry can measure airflow during forced maneuvers and can estimate FVC, FEV1, and peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR). Spirometry cannot measure residual volume and the associated capacities (like TLC/FRC).

 

Other options

 

Option A. Tidal volume (TV): The volume of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing. Can be measured in Spirometry

 

Option B. Vital capacity (VC): The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation. Can be measured in Spirometry

 

Option D. Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1): The volume of air exhaled in the first second of a forced exhalation. Can be measured in Spirometry

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spirometry can measure FVC, FEV1, and TV, but it cannot measure RV or FRC.

choices.text: Normal lung function
Restrictive lung disease
Upper airway obstruction
Obstructive lung disease

questions.text: A patient's flow-volume (FV) loop demonstrates the following (red line in the image is the patients actual FV loop, background blue line is the predicted normal). What does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive lung disease

 

Explanation:

 

The concave shape with scooped appearance of expiratory limb and reduced PEFR on the expiratory limb are classic for obstructive lung diseases like COPD and asthma, indicating airflow limitation during exhalation. The patient also has a near normal FVC, further strengthening the diagnosis of obstruction.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Normal lung function: Normal flow-volume loops are relatively linear.

 

Option B. Restrictive lung disease: Usually shows a smaller loop with normal shape.

 

Option C. Upper airway obstruction: Typically shows flattening on the inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A concave, scooped expiratory flow-volume loop with reduced PEFR is indicative of obstructive lung disease such as COPD or asthma.

choices.text: Trachea
Mainstem bronchi
Medium-sized bronchi
Small airways (bronchioles)

questions.text: A patient with wheezing and shortness of breath undergoes spirometry. A decreased maximum mid-expiratory flow rate (MMEF or FEF25-75%) is observed. Which airways are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small airways (bronchioles)

 

Explanation:

 

MMEF, also known as FEF25-75%, reflects airflow in the small airways (bronchioles). A decrease in MMEF suggests obstruction in these airways, which is a common finding in conditions like asthma and COPD.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Trachea: Obstruction here would cause stridor, a high-pitched sound on inspiration.

 

Option B. Mainstem bronchi: Obstruction here would cause more severe symptoms and a different flow-volume loop pattern.

 

Option C. Medium-sized bronchi: While potentially affected, these airways are not the primary site of obstruction reflected by a decreased MMEF

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decreased MMEF (FEF25-75%) indicates obstruction in the small airways (bronchioles), which is common in asthma and COPD.

choices.text: Asthma
Main bronchus obstruction
Large airway tumor
COPD

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking presents with a new onset of stridor and progressive dyspnea. His flow-volume loop is shown. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Main bronchus obstruction

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has a unilateral mainstem bronchus obstruction. The flow-volume loop shows both an end-inspiratory and end-expiratory tail and is most commonly known as a biphasic flow-volume curve. This finding has also been described as “two compartments.”

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically shows a concave expiratory limb without biphasic flattening.

 

Option C. Large airway tumor: While it can cause fixed obstruction with flattening of both limbs, a biphasic pattern is more indicative of a main bronchus obstruction.

 

Option D. COPD: Shows a concave expiratory limb and does not typically cause a biphasic pattern in the flow-volume loop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A biphasic flow-volume loop indicates a main bronchus obstruction, often presenting with both end-inspiratory and end-expiratory tailing.

choices.text: Spontaneous breathing
Positive pressure ventilation
Airway obstruction
Lung collapse

questions.text: A patient is in ICU and you are noticing the flow-volume loop as shown. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positive pressure ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

In this FV loop expiration precedes inspiration and this is opposite to normal spontaneous respiration. This is due to positive pressure ventilation, where air is forced into the lungs.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Spontaneous breathing: Would show a normal pattern with inspiration preceding expiration.

 

Option C. Airway obstruction: Would cause a concave shape on the expiratory limb.

 

Option D. Lung collapse: Would result in a smaller loop with decreased flows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A flow-volume loop where expiration precedes inspiration indicates positive pressure ventilation, commonly seen in patients receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU.

choices.text: Asthma
Congestive heart failure
Pulmonary hemorrhage
Interstitial lung disease

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with progressive shortness of breath. Pulmonary function tests reveal a decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO). Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of her decreased DLCO?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial lung disease

 

Explanation:

 

Interstitial lung disease, a known complication of rheumatoid arthritis, leads to thickening and fibrosis of the alveolar-capillary membrane, reducing gas diffusion and causing a decrease in DLCO.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asthma: While asthma can cause a reduced DLCO due to air trapping, it is not the most likely cause in this clinical scenario.

 

Option B. Congestive heart failure: Can cause a reduced DLCO due to pulmonary edema, but the patient's history of rheumatoid arthritis makes ILD more likely.

 

Option C. Pulmonary hemorrhage: Can cause a transient increase in DLCO due to the presence of blood in the alveoli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with rheumatoid arthritis and progressive shortness of breath, a decreased DLCO is most likely due to interstitial lung disease, a common pulmonary complication associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

choices.text: Pneumonia
Interstitial lung disease (ILD)
Alveolar hemorrhage
Pleural effusion

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with sudden onset of hemoptysis and shortness of breath. Her DLCO is 163%. What underlying pathology is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alveolar hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presenting with hemoptysis and an increased DLCO, alveolar hemorrhage is the most likely cause. The presence of blood in the alveoli increases the binding capacity for carbon monoxide, thereby increasing DLCO.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Pneumonia: Typically associated with normal or decreased DLCO due to inflammation and consolidation, not an increase.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Usually associated with a decreased DLCO due to fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar-capillary membrane.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: Does not typically affect DLCO in the same manner; it might decrease lung volumes but not directly increase DLCO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased DLCO in a patient with SLE and sudden hemoptysis suggested alveolar hemorrhage, where the presence of blood in the alveoli elevates carbon monoxide binding capacity.

choices.text: Increased DLCO
Normal DLCO
Decreased DLCO
Increased FEV1/FVC ratio

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of systemic sclerosis presents with progressive dyspnea. Which of the following pulmonary function test results would be most consistent with her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased DLCO

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic sclerosis can cause interstitial lung disease (ILD), a condition that decreases the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) due to fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar-capillary membrane.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Increased DLCO: Seen in conditions like asthma, pulmonary hemorrhage, or polycythemia.

 

Option B. Normal DLCO: Unlikely in ILD, which typically causes a reduced DLCO.

 

Option D. Increased FEV1/FVC ratio: Not characteristic of ILD, which is a restrictive pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis can lead to interstitial lung disease (ILD), characterized by a decreased DLCO due to fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar-capillary membrane.

choices.text: Emphysema
Asbestosis
Pneumonia
Bronchogenic carcinoma

questions.text:
A 74-year-old former naval ship worker with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea, dry cough, bilateral end-inspiratory crackles, and no clubbing. PFT is given below.

 

Total lung capacity          67% of predicted

Residual volume              72% of predicted

FVC                                    65% of predicted

FEVI                                   75% of predicted

FEV I/FVC ratio                89% (Normal)

DLCO                                 52% of predicted

 

Chest X-ray reveals bilateral lower zone predominant lesions. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

 

Explanation:

 

The history of asbestos exposure (naval ship worker), progressive dyspnea, dry cough, restrictive PFT pattern, and bilateral lower zone opacities are consistent with asbestosis.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Emphysema: Typically causes obstructive pattern on PFTs, upper lobe predominant changes, and may present with wheezing.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: Usually acute onset with fever and consolidation on imaging.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Often associated with a history of smoking but usually presents as a mass or nodule on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is characterized by a history of asbestos exposure, restrictive PFT pattern, progressive dyspnea, and bilateral lower zone opacities on imaging.

choices.text: Obstructive lung disease
Restrictive lung disease
Normal lung function
Combined obstructive and restrictive lung disease

questions.text: 65-year-old man undergoes pulmonary function testing (PFT) as part of a routine medical health check (MHC). He has no pulmonary issues and is a lifelong non-smoker. The PFT results are shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely consistent with the observed data?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal lung function

 

Explanation:

 

  • The PFT results show normal FVC (102% predicted), FEV1 (95% predicted), FEV1/FVC ratio (73%) and DLCO (84% of predicted)
  • No significant change post-bronchodilator indicates no reversible obstruction.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Obstructive lung disease: Typically has an FEV1/FVC ratio < 70%.

 

Option B. Restrictive lung disease: Typically shows a reduced TLC.

 

Option D. Combined obstructive and restrictive lung disease: Would show both a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal PFT results include an FEV1/FVC ratio around 75-80%, no significant change post-bronchodilator, and normal predicted values for FVC, FEV1, and DLCO.

choices.text: Asthma
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Restrictive lung disease
Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 41-year-old smoker presents with shortness of breath (SOB). His pulmonary function test (PFT) results are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

 

  • The PFT results indicate severe obstruction:
    • FEV1 is markedly reduced (19% predicted).
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is significantly decreased (54%), consistent with obstructive lung disease.
    • RV is increased (257% predicted), indicating air trapping.
    • TLC is within normal limits (108% predicted), ruling out restrictive lung disease.
    • DLCO is severely reduced (3% predicted), consistent with emphysema, a common cause of COPD.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically shows reversible airflow obstruction with significant improvement post-bronchodilator, which is not seen here (FEV1 change of -10%).

 

Option C. Restrictive lung disease: Typically shows a reduced TLC, which is not present in these results.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Generally does not present with such a pronounced obstructive pattern and reduced DLCO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

COPD is characterized by reduced FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, increased RV indicating air trapping, and a reduced DLCO, particularly in cases of emphysema.

choices.text: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Myasthenia gravis
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents for evaluation of shortness of breath on exertion for 2 months. She is a non-smoker and has no prior history of asthma or other pulmonary problems. She works as a receptionist in a hotel and has two cats and three parakeets at home. Her pulmonary function test (PFT) results are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The PFT results indicate a restrictive pattern:
    • FEV1 is significantly reduced (43% predicted).
    • FVC is significantly reduced (40% predicted) suggesting a restrictive pattern.
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is increased (91%), consistent with a restrictive pattern.
    • Total Lung Capacity (TLC) is reduced (44% predicted), confirming a restrictive pattern.
    • DLCO is severely reduced (16% predicted), which is suggestive of intrinsic restriction (ILD)
  • The patient's exposure to birds (parakeets) is a common cause of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, leading to lung inflammation and fibrosis (ILD)

 

Other options

 

Option A. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): Typically shows a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and increased TLC due to air trapping, not a restrictive pattern.

 

Option B. Myasthenia gravis: Can cause a restrictive pattern but typically presents with muscle weakness rather than severe reductions in lung volumes and DLCO.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Generally does not present with a restrictive pattern on PFT and primarily affects DLCO if significant, but not the overall lung volumes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is characterized by a restrictive pattern on PFTs, decreased TLC, and significantly reduced DLCO. Bird exposure, particularly to parakeets, is a common cause.

choices.text: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Myasthenia gravis
Interstitial lung disease (ILD)
Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with worsening shortness of breath on exertion and exercise limitation. She is a lifelong non-smoker and has no significant past medical history. Her pulmonary function test (PFT) results are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia gravis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The PFT results indicate a restrictive pattern:
    • FEV1 is significantly reduced (30% predicted).
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is normal (99%)
    • FVC is significantly reduced (26% predicted) suggesting a restrictive pattern.
    • Total Lung Capacity (TLC) is reduced (53% predicted), confirming a restrictive pattern.
    • RV/TLC ratio is increased (65%), which can be seen in conditions that affect muscle strength.
    • DLCO is relatively normal (84% predicted), which typically occurs in extrinsic restriction.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): Typically shows a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and increased TLC due to air trapping, not a restrictive pattern.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Causes intrinsic restriction hence presents with significant diffusion impairment, often with very low DLCO values.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Generally does not present with a restrictive pattern on PFT and primarily affects DLCO if significant enough, not the overall lung volumes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on PFTs characterized by reduced FEV1 and FVC with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio, reduced TLC, and an increased RV/TLC ratio.
